111.content: You are a young mouse about 16 seasons old called Vaan who is travelling the world seeking adventure. Like your family before you, you are mainly travelling in search of vermin to bring them to justice. The two blades at your side, which you have called Sunrise and Sundown, due to one of them being white coloured and the other black have so far seen many vermin killed. Right now you are in search of a rat horde that had attacked an innocent vole family a few miles away and you have ended up following a path next to a forest you knew was called Mossflower. You end up coming up to a sign that points in two directions. One points to Redwall, the other to Saint Ninians. Where do you go?
111.title: Fork in the road

choices: A young squirrel from the abbey
A rat from a vermin band
A hedgehog who lives in the woods
1111.content: You have heard many stories about Redwall and decide it is time you visited. Besides, you are feeling tired after travelling all day and could do with a bed for the night. After walking for a while you can sense that you are being followed by someone in the woods to your left. Taking no chances, you pull out your swords and run at the creature following you. It turns out to be...
1111.title: Road to Redwall

choices: "Yes! Let's get something to eat".
"I'm fine. Can you show me around the abbey?"
11111.content:
What was that? You stop and turn around, you pull out Sunrise and run.

Whump!

"Hey! Watch it!"
"Who are you!?"
"Get off!"

You get to your feet again to see a bushy, red squirrel holding a basket.

"Oh now look!" he groans, "What'd you jump me like that for!?"
"Sorry...who are you?"
"Waslin, and who, are you?"
"I'm Vaan," you say. You look at his clothes, "Are you from Redwall?" you ask.
"Yes...Will you put that knife away!? You're giving me the jumps!"
"Sorry".

You put Sunrise away and help Waslin gather up his spilt apples and put them back into the basket.
"I want to go to Redwall, where is it?"
"Follow me!" said Waslin, "It's not far, I was heading back myself when you decided to bowl me over!"
"Sorry!"

You keep walking, the sunlight is bright and warm, but a breeze keeps you from sweating. Finally, the redstone belltower of the abbey looms up through the trees.

"There it is!" Waslin points, "Hello there!"

"Who'sa dhere?"

A tiny squirrel hopped up and down on the walltop, staring over the edge. He was barely tall enough to see over the battlements.

"Nutkin! Tell Skipper to open the gates!"
"Wazzles!"
"Go and get the Skipper!"

A fat, red-haired dibbun squirrel bumped down the steps and ran across the yard. "Skippah!...SKIPPAH!!!!"
"Belay there, matey! What's all this about, then?"
"Wazlin's back!"

You reach the huge front gates, Waslin thumps on the door with a clenched paw. The bars are moved aside and the gates are opened. Waslin walks in with you following him.

"Aaah you got the apples for the pie!" says a hedgehog maid, shuffling over, "And who are you, then?" she asks, looking at you.

"I'm Vaan," you say, "Just a...travelling mouse looking for shelter, I've heard so much about Redwall..."
"Hoy, I'm sure you have, matey!" said Skipper, heaving the doors closed and dropping the bars back into place, "You stick wid young Waslin, he'll show you around!"

"Are you hungry?" Waslin asks.
11111.title: Waslin the Squirrel.

choices: Tell him who you really are
The abbot interrupts
111112.content:
"Sure thing!" says Waslin cheerfully. He shows you around the abbey, you take in every little detail, just like you'd been trained to do. It was strange to you though, every creature at the abbey seemed to be very happy. This was completeley different to where you had grown up.
It had been a tough childhood for you, all you had been taught was how to fight. You had never known love or friendship. All you knew was how to fight.
After showing you around the abbey, the last stop was made at the tapestry showing Martin the Warrior.
"Who is that mouse?" you ask, entranced by the tapestry.
Noticing your fascinated expression, Waslin explains. "That is Martin the warrior, the founder of Redwall. He had no fear in battle and even now he is among us, offering guidance to those who need it."
"I see. I'm guessing thats his sword up there" you say, pointing to the sword hanging next to the tapestry.
"Yep. Though it hasnt been used in many seasons."
You take oout your swords.
"I wish it was the same for these." you say.
"What do you mean?" asks Waslin curiously.
You feel like you can trust Waslin, so you decide to...

Arevan asked, There was no response form the pair.For a moment he thought they hsd been killed in the fight but he soon dismissed that thought when he saw both of the maid breathing slowly. 112.title: Squirrel

choices: Collect a goblet from the underwater ruins of a castle along the riverbank
Go to the northen mountains and retrieve a medallion
113.content:
The otter holt of Riverdew was very lively with activity. The current Skipper, Jacob Swiftpaw was retiring, leaving the post open. He had called a meeting of every otter in the holt to decide who his successor would be. The room was full as every otter tried to get comfortable. One otter, Deyna, watched from the back of the room as he leant on the wall, his bright green eyes watching over everything.
The room fell silent as Jacob Swiftpaw entered. He was quite an old otter, yet his face looked young, his eyes still twinkled with youthfull energy.
"haha, it's good to see you all!" he called out, smiling. "I called you all here because as you know, i am retiring. And we need a new skipper!"
He observed them all before continuing, the atmosphere a little tense. "Now I have come up with a fair way to decide who the next sipper will be. However, it will be quite dangerous! those of you who wish to try, raise your paws." he said.
There was an outbreak of noise as the otters discussed what had been just said. Then, five paws were raised. They belonged to Rees, a muscly male otter, Darma, a tall female, Swift, a female with a long tail, Connor, a cheerful young otter and Deyna's.
"haha, ok me bucko's, step forward!" Jacob said. All eyes were on the five otters as they stood in front of him.
"The challenge before you all is dangerous. here is what you must do."
113.title: Otter

choices: Head for Salamandastron, time is of the essence!
Continue his hunt in Mossflower, only a coward would stop now!
(A) Go in search for a badger sow, might be the last bit of fun and pleasure.
114.content:
Starglint, the next badger lord of Salamandastron stood in the middle of Mossflower wood, his bastard sword strapped to his back as he looked around among the trees. The woods were silent underneath the singing of the birds and the chirps of the insects in the humid dusk air. The heavy linen cloak clung tight to his skin, keeping the moisture off of his fur before he started to make his stride. The lord had only recently come into realization that he was to go to the volcanic mountain, as miles away his father, at that moment, finally had succumb to a sea rat attack on the shore, made successful by the efforts of the Long Patrol, but at heavy losses.

Starglint felt the pull to the west, but in his brain rumbled some thoughts. Were he to go straight to the mountain, he would have opportunity to seek revenge and justice for his Father's death, find the band of sea rats and rid the lands of their stinking presence. The yearn for the taste of their blood is strong.

However, in the wood, He had been tracking a band of vermin for nearly two seasons, getting painfully close to their lair. It would feel wrong to simply abandon one's hunt when the price is merely a claw's breadth away.

In a more base need, Starglint pondered to find a badger sow, to give her his heir, so that were he to fall in battle, there would be another to avenge him. His heart raced in such a thought, curling his lips at the prospect.
114.title: Badger Lord

choices: Starglint heads to the barracks, to take out the bulk of the army.
Sneak into the fortress, best to fight along side the Long Patrol.
Head to the vermin leader's yurt, take out the head and the rest will fall.
1141.content:
Starglint shook his head. Now was the time to assume his position as the new Badger Lord, and if his predecessor had fallen, he had better make haste towards his new home to defend it. The heavy boar began his westward sprint through Mossflower woods, passing by river and meadow and village without pause, a critter with a mission.

A week had passed, and Starglint stood at the edge of the beachfront. The full moon filled the night sky with its light and the boar crouched behind several tall stones. Torchlight dotted the beach, and from his vantage point he could see the front entrance of Salamandastron, but there was the issue of the vermin army between himself and his birthright.

Starglint continued to creep towards the beach, moving from stone to stone until there was nothing but sand between himself everyone else. The vermin weren't sending guard patrols except around the volcano, focusing their attention on the inside. Considering the Long Patrol were never known for getting re-enforcements, the battle tactic was sound, however Starglint smiled, feeling quite the spanner to be plunged into their gears. The Badger Lord gripped the hilt of his bastard sword, feeling the rough texture bite into his calloused hand. He had to be careful, he was heavily outnumbered, and they had killed one badger already.

Starglint figured he had three options. The vermin probably are resting after a day of siege, so he could rush into their barracks and take out several of their warriors now, catch them with their breeches 'round their ankles, as it were. He'd have to be quick, and would have to know when to retreat before he got overwhelmed, but it would catch them by surprise. He looked over at Salamandastron's front door, figuring he could possibly sneak into the fortress, that way he could rest, arm and armour himself, and bring on the wrath of the Long Patrol by his side.

Scanning the enemy camp, he saw a large tent, a yurt, with plenty of guards at the front. A wicked smile ran across Starglint's face. He could make his way there and dispatch their boss. A quick tactic there could turn the tides, or at least cause the enemy to disband and make for the hills. He liked that idea muchly, but it did have its risks.
1141.title: New Priorities!

choices: Right for the chief, a quick thrust into the back should end things.
Dispatch the bodyguard, no need to die right after killing the boss.
11413.content:
The temptation was too great for Starglint. A quick sneak attack would cripple the enemy army and hopefully cause the rats to disband and flee. They'd return, but at least that'd give Starglint time to settle down in the fortress. The badger's ebon bladed sword was pulled from his back sheath as he stole his way into the encampment. Several rats and weasels were around a fireplace, drinking up the day's battle, the smell of whiskey strong in the air. Starglint made a mental note to capture their food holds if possible, he could use a good drink.

The badger lord crept up behind the large yurt, carving a slit in the canvas as quietly as he could, checking around him to make sure he wasn't spotted. His heart was pounding in his chest as he peeked inside. The yurt was dark aside from candles being held over a table, all the occupants leaning over it, discussing battle plans. Starglint slowly made the slit wide enough for himself to crawl through, swallowing his breath as to not make a noise. His ears perked to listen.

"We can't keep attacking at the front, it's too well fortified and the bodies of our slain simply are giving them another wall." a scarred weasel muttered, picking his teeth with a stiletto.

"We've looked around this blasted mountain for weeks now, there isn't any other way inside, unless you want to jump into the crater. Maybe you should do that, Toothrot." a fat young rat snarled at the weasel, the latter presumably Toothrot.

"Lieutenants, would you both shut up. Had we some proper siege equipment, we'd be over and done with this already. What we need is a real idea, something that'll work." said an old rat. By the looks, probably the one in charge, especially considering the tall slab of meat that made for an ermine. Both of their backs were to him, and it wouldn't be too hard to take out the boss, though, perhaps it would be more prudent to go after his guard. Starglint did hope to live after this encounter.
11413.title: Into the Lion's Den

choices: The rat chief held a flintlock gun, pointed right at Starglint's belly.
The sea rat had a scroll of parchment, incanting some sort of spell.
114132.content:
Starglint grunted to himself, going right for the burly bodyguard, letting out a bloody roar as he stabbed his blade into the huge beast's back. The ermine let out a yelp as the vermin council stared at the sudden presence of the badger in their tent. Starglint kicked off the bodyguard from his sword, hacking a nearby weasel in two before he could draw his axe. Chaos took over the tent as Starglint went to hack captain after captain, his eyes red with rage.

The older rat dove behind some chests and charts, the chief keeping out of the line of fire for the moment as Starglint destroyed as much as he could. His muscular body rippling as he hunted around for the chief before the armies came, pushing over everything to search. The huge badgerlord soon finding the chief, lifting his sword to vanquish him.

But the sea rat chief had something up his own sleeve, an ace in the hole. Something that Starglint had never seen before.
114132.title: From bottom to top.

choices: Starglint standing still, eyes blank, his mind under the rat's control.
Starglint's cloak and sword on the ground, but no sign of the badger.
1141322.content: “Ke Vash, Auroa, Ministrew!” The sea rat chanted out. Starglint's sword was too heavily embedded in another beast's torso for him to pull it out and stop him. The chief's hand glowed for a bit before firing out at Starglint! Forces from beyond the earthly plane of existence bent and flowed to his call, focusing on his hand and then plunging into the chest of the mighty badger lord! Fire-less, blue smoke filled the tent, making the old sea rat cough and fan his face, trying to breathe, and once he was able to, he saw
1141322.title: Magic?  In Redwall?

choices: Stay in the Chieftain's tent, see if he can't fine something to do to the chief.
Escape from the tent, there's nothing Starglint could possibly do right now!
11413222.content:
The Sea Rat Chieftain let out a cry of victory, moving his foot to kick on the cloak on the ground, making sure that he didn't simply make the badger invisible. Somehow that old vixen witch really did have power, and banished that badger out of this world, or made him not exist, or something. It didn't matter much. He called for some guards to take away the dead bodies, he'll have to appoint new captains tomorrow, but for the moment, he had won. He hefted up the huge ebony bastard sword the badger used, too heavy for him or any of his men to use, but most certainly a trophy befitting such a victory. He looked over the scroll once again, finding the words and symbols written on it disappeared. A one shot device, but at least it did its job.

Starglint blinked slightly, feeling very woozy, despite his berserker rage. He glanced around, trying to get his bearings, feeling terribly lost. Some voices boomed in his head as he looked up, and up, and up, seeing the Chieftain having grown bigger than a mountain! Starglint saw the table he was at, and the dead bodies getting moved off, when he realized that wasn't the case, the mighty badger lord was shrunk to the size of a flea! No, he was the size of a flea's flea! Whatever sorcery was going on was not pleasing him one bit as he looked around, trying to figure out what to do right now.
11413222.title: Starglint's cloak and sword on the ground, ...

choices: He freezes, the hand coming down right on top of him.
He dives to one side, anywhere where he isn't must be better, right? (A)
114132221.content:
Starglint looked around the huge tent. No way would he be able to survive a minute outside with all those guards walking around. Best to stay put for the moment. The badger made his way towards the pile of cushions that seem to service for the rat's bed as the huge sea rat discarded his clothes, cackling to himself as he stretched out. “What an annoyance, but I'm sure the seas and the land will forever know the reign of Thundike the Badgerslayer. Mmmm, I like the sound of that.”

Starglint didn't particularly enjoy the sound of that himself, getting to the cushions as he climbed up towards the rat. He might not be big, but he was still a badger lord, and still rather pissed. Thundike rolled over onto his side, getting himself comfortable, stretching out a bit. A huge rat hand coming down towards Starglint as the badger lord's eyes went wide. He wasn't sure what to do, this whole situation rather new to him!
114132221.title: In the tent

choices: To his mouth to cover a yawn.
Down south for who knows what.
1141322211.content:
The massive paw came right down onto Starglint. At first he thought 'So, this is it, I get killed like an annoying fly.' but soon he realized he couldn't think that if he was still alive. The massive rat hand lifted up, taking Starglint with him as he looked over the huge grey furred creature. He had a big gut on him, but over all he looked rather toned and muscled, and even handsome, well, for a rat anyway.

Thundike stretched again, his hands moving the tiny badger...
1141322211.title: Badger didn't move fast enough.

choices: Thundike stops, feeling himself finished before laying back down.
The rat squeezes his foot firmly, grunting as he tries to get himself worked out
11413222112.content:
Thundike grunted, having been on his feet all day, rolled onto his back, curling his legs toward him and started to knead his calloused soles, groaning in contentment as he worked over his feet. Starglint, going unnoticed, was pressed hard against the musky pads, feeling his body grinding against the rat's flesh as he closed his eyes, his fur rubbing all over the top of the foot, then grunted as the rat moved to push him against the ball of his foot and heel.

He moved over to the other foot, massaging that one equally as well as Starglint was near unconscious from the smell and the battering he was getting against the rat's hand and foot, letting out a soft whimper as he fought to keep up, wiggling more on the rat's palm. He had to keep alive somehow.
11413222112.title: Tired rat needs a rub.

choices: Thundike is asking for one of the female rats in his army.
Thundike calls out for one of the male weasels in his crew.
1141322212.content:
Starglint grunted to himself, seeing the massive hand starting to come down on him and immediately bolted to his right, sending himself hurdling and bouncing off of the cushions, heading heaven knows where. The badger looked disoriented for a moment, trying to find his bearings, but was content to having dodged that hand. His nose inhaling the air, finding it getting thicker, muskier, more rank. He turned around slightly and found himself right above Thundike's sheath, the red tip of his penis already peeking out and leaking his slick fluids.

The sea rat grunted a bit more, that huge hand reaching to squeeze the base of his furry sheath, spilling more of his shaft into the air, getting the musky flesh to grind against Starglint's body. The rat cooing a bit more as he looks around. Seems like Thundike is considering something as Starglint could feel the rat's heartbeat increase. His furless hand rubbing over his cock as the huge rat made his choice, lifting up his head to call out.
1141322212.title: From the hand to the pole.

choices: Attack an eye
Go to the next ear, tell him to restore him, or else...
11413222122.content:
"Quwelp! Quwelp!, rot you, get in here"
A raggedy vermin came in, bowing, and hat off.
"Y-yes M'Lord?"
" Quwelp! Get a maid in here! I'm in the mood!"
Quwelp bowed and backed out the door. Starglint still didn't quite know what to do at his size. However, he was a Badgerlord. He was a warrior, true born. He wasn't going to let his condition stop him from his goal.
Then, he got an idea, and made way across Thundike's body, up towards his scaly head. Climbing over his cheek, he had to dodge the sea rat's claw a few times. It was obvious that he was itching him. Good. That was just the beginning of Starglint's plan.
He scurried up to the ear and climbed in. It was full of dirt and wax, so it was slow going, and disgusting. All this time, Thundike was grumbling about was taking Quwelp so long with the maiden. What maiden wouldn't want him? He licked his lips in anticipation, if only he could stop this blasted itch.
Inside the sea rat's ear, Starglint had reached his destination, the eardrum. He could see it vibrating, from all of the sounds coming in from around it. Perfect. Filling his lungs, the badger roared out the largest cry he could. The sea rat yelped in pain and grabbed his ear. Starglint did it again, and the sea rat shook his head in pain. Inside the ear, the badger held on as best he could.. Now for part two.
Using his sharp claws, Starglint attacked the membrane of the eardrum. He created slashes in it that while, didn't bleed, looked very nasty and painful. Thundike yowled and fell in the floor, rolling in pain. At that moment, Quwelp returned with a not very comely looking rat maiden. They both looked at each other in confusion
" 'e havin' one of dem seizures?" asked the rat maiden.
"Dunno." replied Quwelp. He tried to approach Thundike, but was afraid to.
Inside Thundike's ear, Starglint continued his assault, shredding the eardrum. There was some blood now, and the badger was sure that the sea rat was deafened in this ear.
He started to scramble out of the rat's ear, which was difficult, with him rolling around. His claws helped. What to do next, he thought?
Should he
11413222122.title: Thundike calls out for one of the male weasels ...

choices: agree
say no, never!
114132221222.content:
Starglint had to use his claws to make his way out of the searat's now useless ear.Thundike had his paw over it, still whimpering, but the badger managed to work his way through them, then up the greasy head towards the other ear.
"Uh... M-M'Lord?" Quwelp approached the now silent Thundike. "A--are you quite all right, Sir?"
Quwelp had the misfortune of approaching from the now deaf side of Thundike. As he neared, Thundike saw him, hissed, and flung one arm out at him, catching him off guard. Quwelp took a blow to his belly, doubled over, then to his knees.
"Sir?"
Thundike got up, looking at Quwelp.
"Sir!?" again mumbled the servant rat.
"What's that you say? Speak up Quwelp. I'm in no mood for games!" yelled Thundike.
" I am talking, M'Lord, I..."
Thundike kicked Quwelp.
"I told you to speak! I hear nothing but wind from your mouth!"
All this time Starglint had been been working his way over the rat's head into the ear. At the same time, he had to evade his ever scratching claw as well. Apparently Thundike couldn't figure out he was deaf in one ear yet. Well, that's a Searat for you, thought Starglint. Can't see the forest for the trees. At the same time, the rat maiden had retreated back to the wall, watching the events unfold. She picked a wrong time to join up with this bully crew, she thought.
Finally Starglint had reached the rat's remaining eardrum. Now that he had shown Thundike what he could do, he would give him an ultimatum.
"Thundike!"
The searat yelped in pain agian, much to the relief of Quwelp. He yelled again "Thundike!"
"Ahhhr! Whose that?"
"Starglint!"
"No, no, yer gone! I saw it myself! I destroyed ye.!"
"I'm here, Searat, feel it!" Starglint poked a claw in the eardrum, causing a wave of pain to go through the searat's head. He held his paw to his ear and yelped again.
Quwelp and the maiden had both retreated to the wall by now, looking at each other.
"Oo's he talkin' to?" she asked.
"I don't know." replied Quwelp, rubbing his sore ribs.
"Maybe's e's seein ghosts or sumtin!"
"I think we should leave." They both scurried off as fas
t as they could.
Starglint had heard them, and chuckled a little at it.
"I'm here inside you, Searat! I made you deaf in your one ear! I could do the same here!"
"No, please"
" Then maybe your eyes! Imagine, no sight, so sound, no being anything but a pathetic beggar, if that."
Thundike shivered.
"Think of your enemies! You'd be easy prey for them! Maybe they wouldn't even kill you, but keep you locked in a cage somewhere!"
"STOP IT! What in the Sea's name do you want?" shrieked Thundike.
" A coward always shows his true stripes in a crisis." said Starglint. "Simple. Use whatever magic you did to restore me, or face the fate I told you."

Does Thundike ...
114132221222.title: Go to the next ear, tell him to restore him, or...

choices: Shock and awe in a full frontal assault.
Stealthfully dispatch the vermin after nightfall.
Retreat now, and return later with some backup.
1142.content:
"Now isn't the time to be thinking of fornication or of running off. I've spent this long tracking these vermin, and I will complete my task." Starglint muttered to himself, making his way along the trail he had been tracking for so long. Many a trail turned into dead ends, but as of late this band of bandits have been slipping up, and making more mistakes. They have caught wind of someone looking for them and they've been moving more swiftly, but a fleeting prey is easier to spot than one standing still.

Starglint smiled, seeing a cave in the heart of Mossflower wood. A few weasel guards are on patrol, with bardiches resting on their shoulders, several more rats and other vermin inside the patrol line, all around the mouth of the cave. He wasn't sure how many were inside, or how cavernous the underworld would be in there.

Slowly he drew his bastard sword, Efreeti, from its backsheath, getting the weapon at the ready. The warrior took some time to consider his plan of attack, not wanting to blow this chance after so long in its conception. A full on attack might be possible at this moment, while they were on their own ground, they did not seem quite prepared as most of the guards were remaining inattentive. He might have been downwind from the bandits, but a massive, black and white badger is not easy to miss.

Starglint could also wait until nightfall, when most of the prey would be asleep. Slightly more cowardly in combat, however, considering the numbers, might be smarter to fight such large odds.

Finally, Starglint considered leaving now, and returning with a larger task force. While it might end up losing the trail of the bandits, but, the cave might be a base of operations, and still be around when he gets back.
1142.title: Finishing a task.

choices: Charge in after them, leave them no ground to retreat to.
Wait for them to come into the open.
11421.content:
Starglint was tired of waiting, and wanted to settle the score as soon as possible. With the call of Bloodwrath overcoming the brock, the new lord took both of his hands to his blade, charging out into the clearing before the cave entrance.

The ebon blade of Efreeti sang a sharp whistle, and the first weasel guard was felled before even a word was spoken. The dull thud of his skull on the soft peat caused the nearby rats to shriek in alarm. The weasels pounced towards Starglint, polearms shining in the air, easily blocked by the beserk badger. The fiery song of Efreeti lashed out, running across the belly of one of the adversaries, opening him up like a Christmas present. Several rats jumped upon his back, burying their daggers into the badger's shoulders, making him roar in pain. Starglint quickly undid his cloak, now naked before his enemies, chopping his blade down upon his dropped cloak several times before the contents underneath it stopped squirming and the brown fabric was stained red.

Starglint shrugged off several darts and bolts that shrieked into his hide, sprinting to the three crossbowmen near the cave's maw. Before the rats had time to reload, the badger's massive hand descended upon one rat, crushing his skull, his blade dispatched the other two with one weighty blow.

Magdeline Stoutpaw was a young otter who has seen better days. Half a month ago. Her tiny beach side home was ransacked without warning by a group of vile corsairs. Her parents, and older siblings fought valiantly. While the eight-year-old Maggy was ordered to hide in the cellar. It was all for naught, as by the time she was dragged out by a burly stoat, her family was nowhere to be seen. She had prayed that they had gotten away safely. But she knew they wouldn't have abandoned her. She could only take solace in the fact that she didn't see any corpses as she was taken from her home. She had then spent a miserable two weeks in the hull of a nasty corsair ship.

Maggy had almost consigned herself to her fate when she was knocked from her tiny cot. It took her a minute to come to her senses and realize that the ship has been rammed. Several of the pirate crew could be heard screaming and swearing. As she got back to her feet, she could hear loud footsteps storming the deck of the ship. It was being boarded. Maggy allowed herself a brief hope that they were otters or other good beasts taking the fight to the vermin pirates. But even at a young age, she knew that was unlikely. Good beasts dont go looking for a fight. This was vermin preying on their own kind. What was probably about an hour felt like an eternity as Maggy listened to the carnage above. Finally, things quieted down. She heard footsteps and voices. One of them was particularly forceful. A captain giving orders, she assumed. Maggy knew it was only a matter of time before they came down below to loot. They would take her to sell, themselves. She thought. A trio of rats made their way down the crude ramp and started to ransack the place. It wasn't long before one of them set eyes upon the young otter and pipped his head. The three rats huddled together briefly before one of them scurried back up. Maggy could hear the rat's footsteps followed by the heavy pounding of boots. The rat returned with rather large fox. The fox was relatively well dressed. It was clear who was in charge.

"She'd fetch quite the price, Cap'n." One of the rats said. The fox nodded.
"Aye. That she would. But we have our own business to tend to. And the cost of feedin' her wouldn't even be worth it. Leave her. Get all the provisions and valuables back to our ship!" The captain ordered. Not even making eye contact with the little otter. Maggy's blood ran cold. They were just going to leave her to die.

"Wait!" She called out desperately. The captain stopped and turned around to face her.
"Please, don't leave me here!" She begged. Usually a fruitless endevor with vermin. The fox shrugged and smirked.
"Sorry, lass. We've better things to do than deal in living beasts. You're not worth selling. And if we have no use for you, we're not taking you." The captain said calmly. Maggy began to tear up.

"I-I could work. I can cook, and clean, a-and even sew!" she said. The captain stroked the scruff of his chin. He motioned to the three rats, and they all huddled together. Conversing quietly. Maggy watched them intently as they whispered. Every few seconds, one of them would look over towards her and giggle.
"Cap'n! She's just a pup!" One of the rats said in obviously fake protest. A few seconds later, one of the rats went up to the deck while the fox aproached the otter. Maggy didn't like the way he smiled at her. She instinctively backed away as the vermin captain unsheathed a dagger and easily pried off the flimsy lock from her cage. Instead of coming in or pulling her out, he then backed away to a bench against the wall.

"Alright, girly. You want in on my crew? Come closer and start convincin'!" He said. The otter nervously aproached the fox. As she took slow deliberate steps, the fox did something strange. He brought his foot over his other thigh and prided his heavy boot from his foot. He then did the other. Even from a few feet away, the stink of his freshly-freed paws hit the poor girl like a brick to the face. Maggy didn't like where this was going, but she took the last few steps until she was right in front of his. The young otter looked at the fox and waited.

"Now kneel." The fox commanded. Maggy complied. The pirate captain didn't waste any time plopping one of his huge paws right onto her lap. Maggie's mouth scrunched up and she whimpered. His sole took nearly all of her vision. With the heel resting on her lap, his toes reached well above the tip of her scalp. While her eyes got a nice look at the filthy ball of his foot. Not to mention her nose being less than an inch away from it's surface. As she sucked in the stink of his massive paw, Maggie became very scared and very disgusted. The fox didn't say anything for about a minute. Savoring the look on the otter's face as he peeked from behind his foot. Poor Maggie could only sit there in silence as she tried not to gag at the sour stink.

"Grab a hold of my foot. Use both hands, now." The fox ordered. Maggy reluctantly complied. getting a grip of the sides of his foot with both paws. her thumbs pressed against his sole. She could feel the warm, most film of sweat on her hands now. gritty from the dirt covering his sole.

"Do ya know what this is, Lassie?" The fox asked. Maggie shook her head.

"Tis a calendar. Educated beasts use it to track the days and the seasons. We're going to use it to mark your... duties. Today is October seventeenth. It doesn't have an x on it, see?" The fox said, pointing at the current day's box. Maggy nodded. The fox continued.
